paragraph: Paul went straight to the fire, and stood staring into it with lack-lustre eye, too apathetic even to be hopeless, for the work of enlightening the Doctor seemed more terrible and impossible than ever, and he began to see that, if the only way of escape lay there, he had better make up his mind with what philosophy he could to adapt himself to his altered circumstances, and stay on for the rest of the term.

paragraph: Then he crossed over to Paul and laid a hand gently on his shoulder. "Look here," he said: "why don't you confide in me? Do you think I'm blind to what has happened to you? I can see the change in you--if others cannot. Why not trust me?"

paragraph: "There were faults on both sides, I fear," said Mr. Blinkhorn, growing a little scandalised by the boy's odd warmth of expression. "I have heard something of what you had to bear with. On the one hand, a father, undemonstrative, stern, easily provoked; on the other, a son, thoughtless, forgetful, and at times it may be even wilful. But you are too sensitive; you think too much of what seems to me a not unnatural (although of course improper) protest against coldness and injustice. I should be the last to encourage a child against a parent, but, to comfort your self-reproach, I think it right to assure you that, in my judgment, the outburst you refer to was very excusable."

paragraph: "You must be calm, Bultitude, or I shall leave you. Listen to reason. You are here for your good. Youth, it has been beautifully said, is the springtime of life. Though you may not believe it, you will never be happier than you are now. Our schooldays are----"

paragraph: But Mr. Bultitude could not tamely be mocked with the very platitudes that had brought him all his misery--he cut the master short in a violent passion. "This is too much!" he cried--"you shall not palm off that miserable rubbish on me. I see through it. It's a plot to keep me here, and you're in it. It's false imprisonment, and I'll write to the _Times_. I'll expose the whole thing!"

paragraph: "This violence is only ridiculous," said Mr. Blinkhorn. "If I were not too pained by it, I should feel it my duty to report your language to the Doctor. As it is, you have bitterly disappointed me; I can't understand it at all. You seemed so subdued, so softened lately. But until you come to me and say you regret this, I must decline to have anything more to say to you. Take your book and sit down in your place!"

paragraph: And he went back to his exercises, looking puzzled and pained. The fact was, he was an ardent believer in the Good Boy of a certain order of school tales--the boy who is seized with a sudden conviction of the intrinsic baseness of boyhood, and does all in his power to get rid of the harmful taint; the boy who renounces his old comrades and his natural tastes (which after all seldom have any serious harm in them), to don a panoply of priggishness which is too often kick-proof.

paragraph: This kind of boy is rare enough at most English schools, but Mr. Blinkhorn had been educated at a large Nonconformist College, where "Revivals" and "Awakenings" were periodical, and undoubtedly did produce changes of character violent enough, but sadly short in duration.
tokens: kind boy rare most english school educate large nonconformist periodical produce change character violent short duration

He was left to rely on his own resources, and he had begun to lose all confidence in their power to extricate him.

paragraph: His thoughts were busy with Dick. Oddly enough, it had scarcely occurred to him before to speculate on what he might be doing in his absence; he had thought chiefly about himself. But now he gave his attention to the subject, what new horrors it opened up! What might not become of his well-conducted household under the rash rule of a foolish schoolboy! The office, too--who could say what mischief Dick might not be doing there, under the cover of his own respectable form?

paragraph: Some may wonder, when they hear what it was, why he never thought of it before, and it is somewhat surprising, but by no means without precedent. When it did, he opened the window and got out.

paragraph: Perhaps a similar passiveness on Mr. Bultitude's part was due to a very natural and proper desire to do everything without scandal, and in a legitimate manner; to march out, as it were, with the honours of war. paragraph: He had still--thank Heaven--the five shillings he had given Dick. He had not thrown them away with the other articles in his mad passion. Five shillings was not much, but it was more than enough to pay for a third-class fare to town. He had only to watch his opportunity, slip away to the station, and be at home again, defying the usurper, before anyone at Crichton House had discovered his absence.

paragraph: At the other end of the table Biddlecomb had again dexterously allured Herr Stohwasser into the meshes of conversation; this time upon the question (_à propos de bottes_) of street performances. "I vill tell you a gurious thing," he was saying, "vat happened to me de oder day ven I vas valking down de Strandt. I saw a leedle gommon dirty boy with a tall round hat on him, and he stand in a side street right out in de road, and he take off his tall round hat, and he put it on de ground, and he stand still and look zo at it. So I shtop too, to see vat he vould do next. And bresently he take out a large sheet of baper and tear it in four pieces very garefully, and stick zem round de tall round hat, and put it on his head again, and zen he set it down on de grount and look at it vonce more, and all de time he never speak von vort. And I look and look and vonder vat he would do next. And a great growd of beoples com, and zey look and vonder too. And zen all at once de leedle dirty boy he take out all de paper and put on de hat, and he valk avay, laughing altogetter foolishly at zomzing I did not understand at all. I haf been thinking efer since vat in the vorldt he do all zat nonsence for. And zere is von ozer gurious thing I see in your London streets zat very same day. Zere vas a poor house cat dat had been by a cab overrun as I passed by, and von man vith a kind varm heart valk up and stamp it on de head for to end its pain. And anozer man vith anozer kind heart, he gom up directly and had not seen de cat overrun, but he see de first man stamping and he knock him down for ill-treating animals; it was quite gurious to see; till de policeman arrest dem both for fighting. Goggs, degline 'Katze,' and gif me ze berfect and bast barticiple of 'kampfen,' to fight." This last relapse into duty was caused by the sudden entrance of the Doctor, who stood at the door looking on for some time with a general air of being intimately acquainted with Schiller as an author, before suggesting graciously that it was time to dismiss the class.

paragraph: Wednesday was a half-holiday at Crichton House, and so, soon after dinner, Paul found himself marshalled with the rest in a procession bound for the football field. They marched two and two, Chawner and three of the other elder boys leading with the ball and four goal-posts ornamented with coloured calico flags, and Mr. Blinkhorn and Mr. Tinkler bringing up the rear.
tokens: half holiday dinner find marshall rest procession bind football field march other elder boy lead ball goal post ornament coloured calico flag bring rear

paragraph: Mr. Bultitude was paired with Tom Grimstone, who, after eyeing him askance for some time, could control his curiosity no longer.
tokens: pair eye askance time control curiosity

paragraph: "I say, Dick," he began, "what's the matter with you this term?"
tokens: say begin matter term

paragraph: "My name is not Dick," said Paul stiffly.
tokens: name say

paragraph: "Oh, if you're so particular then," said Tom: "but, without humbug, what is the matter?"
tokens: particular say humbug matter

paragraph: "You see a change then," said Paul, "you do see a difference, eh?"
tokens: see change say see difference

paragraph: "Rather!" said Tom expressively. "You've come back what I call a beastly sneak, you know, this term. The other fellows don't like it; they'll send you to Coventry unless you take care."
tokens: say come call beastly sneak know term other fellow like send take care

paragraph: "I wish they would," said Paul.
tokens: wish say

paragraph: "You don't talk like the same fellow either," continued Tom; "you use such fine language, and you're always in a bait, and yet you don't stick up for yourself as you used to. Look here, tell me (we were always chums), is it one of your larks?"
tokens: talk same fellow continue use such fine language bait stick use look tell chum lark

paragraph: "Larks!" said Paul. "I'm in a fine mood for larks. No, it's not one of my larks."
tokens: lark say fine mood lark lark

paragraph: "Perhaps your old governor has been making a cad of himself then, and you're out of sorts about it."
tokens: old governor make cad sort

paragraph: "I'll thank you not to speak about him in that way," said Paul, "in my presence."
tokens: thank speak way say presence

paragraph: "Why," grumbled Tom, "I'm sure you said enough about him yourself last term. It's my belief you're imitating him now."
tokens: grumble sure say last term belief imitate

paragraph: "Ah," said Paul, "and what makes you think that?"
tokens: say make think

paragraph: "Why, you go about strutting and swelling just like he did when he came about sending you here. I say, do you know what Mums said about him after he went away?"
tokens: go strutt swell come send say know mum say go

paragraph: "No," said Paul, "your mother struck me as a very sensible and agreeable woman--if I may say so to her son."
tokens: say mother strike sensible agreeable woman say son

paragraph: "Well, Mums said your governor seemed to leave you here just like they leave umbrellas at picture galleries, and she believed he had a large-sized money-bag inside him instead of a heart."
tokens: mum say governor seem leave leave umbrella picture gallery believe have large sized money bag heart

paragraph: "Oh!" said Paul, with great disgust, for he had thought Mrs. Grimstone a woman of better taste; "your mother said that, did she? Vastly entertaining to be sure--ha, ha! He would be pleased to know she thought that, I'm sure."
tokens: say great disgust think woman good taste mother say entertaining sure pleased know think sure

paragraph: "Tell him, and see what he says," suggested Tom; "he is an awful brute to you though, isn't he?"
tokens: tell see say suggest awful brute

paragraph: "If," growled Mr. Bultitude, "slaving from morning till night to provide education and luxury for a thankless brood of unprofitable young vipers is 'being a brute,' I suppose he is."
tokens: growl slave morning night provide education luxury thankless brood unprofitable young viper brute suppose

paragraph: "Why, you're sticking up for him now!" said Tom. "I thought he was so strict with you. Wouldn't let you have any fun at home, and never took you to pantomimes?"
tokens: stick say think strict let have fun home take pantomime

paragraph: "And why should he, sir, why should he? Tell me that. Tell me why a man is to be hunted out of his comfortable chair after a well-earned dinner, to go and sit in a hot theatre and a thorough draught, yawning at the miserable drivel managers choose to call a pantomime? Now in my young days there _were_ pantomimes. I tell you, sir, I've seen----"
tokens: sir tell tell man hunt comfortable chair earn dinner go sit hot theatre thorough draught yawn miserable drivel manager choose call pantomime young day pantomime tell sir see

paragraph: "Oh, if you're satisfied, I don't care!" said Tom, astonished at this apparent change of front. "If you choose to come back and play the corker like this, it's your look-out. Only, if you knew what Sproule major said about you just now----"
tokens: satisfied care say astonished apparent change front choose come play corker look know major say

paragraph: "I don't want to know," said Paul; "it doesn't concern me."
tokens: want know say concern

paragraph: "Perhaps it doesn't concern you what pa thinks either? Dad told Mums last night that he was altogether at a loss to know how to deal with you, you had come back so queer and unruly. And he said, let me see, oh, he said that 'if he didn't see an alteration very soon he should resort to more drastic measures'--drastic measures is Latin for a whopping."
tokens: concern think dad tell mum last night loss know deal come queer unruly say let see say see alteration resort more drastic measure drastic measure whopping

paragraph: "Good gracious!" thought Paul, "I haven't a moment to lose! he might 'resort to drastic measures' this very evening. I can't change my nature at my time of life. I must run for it, and soon."
tokens: good gracious think have moment lose resort drastic measure very evening change nature time life run

paragraph: Then he said aloud to Tom, "Can you tell me, my--my young friend, if, supposing a boy were to ask to leave the field--saying for instance that he was not well and thought he should be better at home--whether he would be allowed to go?"
tokens: say tell young friend suppose boy ask leave field say instance think good home allow go

paragraph: "Of course he would," said Tom, "you ought to know that by this time. You've only to ask Blinkhorn or Tinkler; they'll let you go right enough."
tokens: course say know time ask let go

paragraph: Paul saw his course quite clearly now, and was overcome with relief and gratitude. He wrung the astonished Tom's hand warmly; "Thank you," he said, briskly and cheerfully, "thank you. I'm really uncommonly obliged to you. You're a very intelligent boy. I should like to give you sixpence."
tokens: see course overcome relief gratitude wrung astonished hand thank say thank oblige intelligent boy like give sixpence

paragraph: But although Tom used no arguments to dissuade him, Mr. Bultitude remembered his position in time, and prudently refrained from such ill-judged generosity. Sixpences were of vital importance now, when he expected to be starting so soon on his perilous journey.
tokens: use argument dissuade remember position time refrain such ill judge generosity sixpence vital importance expect start perilous journey

paragraph: And so they reached the field where the game was to be played, and where Paul was resolved to have one desperate throw for liberty and home. He was more excited than anxious as he thought of it, and it certainly did seem as if all the chances were in his favour, and that fortune must have forsaken him indeed, if anything were allowed to prevent his escape.
tokens: reach field game play resolve have desperate throw liberty home excited anxious think seem chance favour fortune forsaken allow prevent escape
